snippet: The high costs of subsidized crop insurance were mostly a result of policies that paid farmers for declines in their income, not of poor crop yields.
abstract: Study financed by Washington research group Environmental Working Group finds that high costs of federal crop insurance program are mainly result of policies that pay farmers for declines in their income, not of poor crop yields; study comes as lawmakers are preparing to work on new farm bill.
lead_paragraph: The high costs of subsidized crop insurance were mostly a result of policies that paid farmers for declines in their income, not of poor crop yields.

headline.seo: Crop Insurance Swells Beyond Disaster Aid, Study Says
